Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and describing foods in other ways during plowboy days in Southern Canada.

Include photos of stories, diaries, and other details. Use back of page if more space is needed.

During the years of the First World War my mother lived in the town of Hamilton, Ontario. She had to take a job frequently because of the economic times. She had to sell what she had left over during the winter and relied on her own resources. Publicly funded programs were not available at that time.
Since starting housekeeping myself I have always lived in town and have never had any difficulty in obtaining much the same types of foods as we use today. Quick frozen foods, prepared cake mixes, quick rising yeast & the different varieties of strained baby foods have all been put on the market since I first started housekeeping.

During the years of the First war my Mother used Corn meal, Rye flour, Graham flour etc., along with white. She had to take a certain quantity of these coarse types in order to obtain white flour. Meat was usually frozen during the winter & salted for summer. Pork was fried & sealed down in...

By permission of the police, we will call him "Party." He was
a large dark man about six feet tall with a pointed
nose and a scar across his face. He spoke in a low voice and
would not look at us. He seemed very nervous when he
spoke. I remember him saying, "I'm innocent."

In conclusion, the key to successful application of principles is to maintain flexibility and adaptability to changing circumstances. The methods and techniques used should be flexible enough to accommodate different situations and needs.
